comment.body: These are good tests assuming all nodes are up, but I think we should have some failure tests too. Where we test the 2PC failure/retry logic.

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,7 @@
+CREATE OR REPLACE FUNCTION pg_catalog.citus_mark_object_distributed(classId Oid, objectName text, objectId Oid)
comment.body:
I think allowing regular users to call this function is a recipe for security problems. e.g. users with very low permissions could mark objects distributed that are not. Or could mark things as distributed that don't even exist. I'm not sure what happens in those cases, but I'm pretty sure lots of stuff will break (like adding new nodes). And having a user with very low permissions cause that kind of breakage is not a good thing.

I think we might want to have these connections to localhost to the main db use superuser instead, so that we can have this function (and probably some of the others), be executable by superuser only. This does bring some other security concerns though. We must make sure we're not executing anything as superuser that's not strictly needed. The commands in the main_db on the are harmless afaict (assuming we escape the arguments correctly). However, we'd want to execute the actual commands on the workers still as the user that the outer transaction uses. So we'd have to pass that along somehow. The easiest way seems to me to pass it as a second argument to either `execute_command_on_other_nodes` or to `citus_internal_start_management_transaction`.

+void
+MarkObjectDistributedWithName(const ObjectAddress *distAddress, char* objectName)
+{
+	if (!IsCitusMainDB())
comment.body:
I feel like if `CitusHasBeenLoaded()` returns true we should still mark this object as distributed, even if the current database is not marked as the main database.
```suggestion
	if (!CitusHasBeenLoaded())
```

comment.body:
Because you don't double quote the function name it's converted to all lowercase by postgres. It seems less confusing to simply define it using lowercase letters.
```suggestion
CREATE OR REPLACE FUNCTION pg_catalog.commit_management_command_2pc()
```

Also, style wise, I don't think I'm a fan of mixing lowercase and uppercase snake_case in the same name. Although an argument can be made when part of the name is an acronym.

pull_request.title: Start Maintenance Daemon for Main DB at the server start.
pull_request.body:
DESCRIPTION: This change starts a maintenance deamon at the time of server start if there is a designated main database.

This is the code flow:

1. User designated an admin database:
   `ALTER SYSTEM SET citus.main_db =  "myadmindb";`

2. When postmaster starts, in _PG_Init, citus calls 
    `InitializeMaintenanceDaemonForMainDb`
  
    This function registers a background worker to run `CitusMaintenanceDaemonMain `with `databaseOid = 0 `

3. `CitusMaintenanceDaemonMain ` takes some special actions when databaseOid is 0:
     - Gets the citus.main_db  value.
     - Connects to the  citus.main_db
     - Now the `MyDatabaseId `is available, creates a hash entry for it.
     - Then follows the same control flow as for a regular db,

license.name: GNU Affero General Public License v3.0
GNU Affero General Public License v3.0

commits.message: Add dependency installation for check-failure tests

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -271,66 +339,97 @@ WarnMaintenanceDaemonNotStarted(void)
 
 
 /*
- * CitusMaintenanceDaemonMain is the maintenance daemon's main routine, it'll
- * be started by the background worker infrastructure.  If it errors out,
- * it'll be restarted after a few seconds.
+ * ConnectToDatabase connects to the database for the given databaseOid.
+ * if databaseOid is 0, connects to MainDb and then creates a hash entry.
+ * If a hash entry cannot be created for MainDb it exists the process requesting a restart.
+ * However for regular databases, it exits without requesting a restart since another
+ * subsequent backend should be starting the Maintenance Deamon.
+ * If a hash entry found has a valid workerPid, it exits
+ * without requesting a restart since there is already a deamon running.
comment.body:
rewording + typo fixes

```suggestion
 * ConnectToDatabase connects to the database for the given databaseOid.
 * if databaseOid is 0, connects to MainDb and then creates a hash entry.
 * If a hash entry cannot be created for MainDb it exists the process requesting a restart.
 * However for regular databases, it exits without requesting a restart since another
 * subsequent backend should be starting the Maintenance Daemon.
 * If the found hash entry has a valid workerPid, it exits
 * without requesting a restart since there is already a daemon running.
```

pull_request.title: Start Maintenance Daemon for Main DB at the server start.
pull_request.body:
DESCRIPTION: This change starts a maintenance deamon at the time of server start if there is a designated main database.

This is the code flow:

1. User designated an admin database:
   `ALTER SYSTEM SET citus.main_db =  "myadmindb";`

2. When postmaster starts, in _PG_Init, citus calls 
    `InitializeMaintenanceDaemonForMainDb`
  
    This function registers a background worker to run `CitusMaintenanceDaemonMain `with `databaseOid = 0 `

3. `CitusMaintenanceDaemonMain ` takes some special actions when databaseOid is 0:
     - Gets the citus.main_db  value.
     - Connects to the  citus.main_db
     - Now the `MyDatabaseId `is available, creates a hash entry for it.
     - Then follows the same control flow as for a regular db,

issue.title: Support replacing IPv6 Loopback in `normalize.sed`
issue.body:
I had a test failure issue due to my machine using the IPv6 loopback address. This change to the `normalize.sed` solves that issue.

DESCRIPTION: Fix `multi_move_mx` test failure when using IPv6 loopback address.

comment.body:
> I had a test failure issue due to my machine using the IPv6 loopback address. This change to the `normalize.sed` solves that issue.
> 
> DESCRIPTION: Fix `multi_move_mx` test failure when using IPv6 loopback address.

Hey @jurplel,

We add `DESCRIPTION: `line to the PRs only if they propose a user-facing change, so we can safely remove it from the PR description.
